A poltergeist's eye.
An electrochimera kidney.
Yeah, just asking.
You were told, not before two days.
You were told, not before two days.
You were told, not before two days.
You were told, not before two days.
Looks like the clock's acting up.
I don't recall you leaving a hand.
I don't recall you leaving a paw.
I don't recall you leaving an eye.
I don't recall you leaving a kidney.
Must've mixed it up, my memory's failing me.
I've got the hand, take it out?
I've got the paw, take it out?
I've got the eye, take it out?
I've got the kidney, take it out?
Take it out.
I'll pick it up later.
Take it out.
I'll pick it up later.
Take it out.
I'll pick it up later.
Take it out.
I'll pick it up later.
Take your rotten hand back. It's just taking up space.
Take your spoiled paw back. It's just taking up space.
Take your wormy eye back. It's just taking up space.
Take your stinking kidney back. It's just taking up space.
I'll drop by again.
I'm looking for someone. Goes by Vasya. He's got a distinctive shotgun — a TOZ-66, side-by-side. Should've passed through here recently, around these parts. Has he stopped by you?
Let me think... one stalker with a shotgun like that did swing by for some sausage. Didn't stay to drink the mash with us, grabbed supplies and took off right away. Haven't seen him since.
Which way did he head?
Along the dirt road that runs north from here, headed toward the ruined bridge.
Got it, thanks.
I need to sharpen a knife.
Don't even bring me that local junk the traders peddle. It's only good for picking your teeth. Easier to buy a new one, or better yet — grab a dozen at once. One for every can you open. Heh-heh.
No, that's not it — I've got the knife you gave me yourself.
Ah, that one... Then no problem. For the work, you'll owe me a medical kit: army or scientific. Or a couple of anti-rads.
I'll keep that in mind.
Can we work something out about sharpening the knife?
Only out of respect for your achievements, Marked One. Got any medicine?
I'm busy right now! Come back later.
Here you go — a couple of anti-rads and the knife.
Here you go — an army medkit and the knife.
Here you go — a scientific medkit and the knife.
Just asking.
Take a walk for about twenty minutes. It's delicate work — doesn't like being rushed.
Better take an interest in girls. Heh-heh...
How's my knife doing? Is it ready?
Take it, use it.
You're a quick one. Take another walk.
Sidor! What kind of crap did you slip me?
Don't yell. My head's been pounding since morning as it is. What are you talking about?
Your knife... real good one. Opened a can, sliced some bread, picked my teeth — and it's already dull as a felt boot.
Some teeth you've got there, Marked One. Solid steel, huh. Heh-heh.

I'm serious. Some good folks told me how you make money off defective junk. Couldn't you have handed out something better? What, you expect me to run and buy a new knife every day? I'll be flat broke like that — you know I've only just started getting back on my feet.
Alright, stop whining. I don't have any other knives — can only give you another one just like it. People these days… they get stuff for free and still aren't happy...
Oh sure, sure. First you get people hooked on cheap junk, then you complain when they start making claims...
Don't like my junk — look for goods somewhere else. That's it, get lost, I'm sick of your grumbling.
Can you sharpen a knife?

A knife? One of those Sidorovich sells? Crap, not knives. The military once brought a whole batch of defective ones into the Zone. You can't even open a tin can properly with them. Brittle steel — they dull and break fast. So toss it and buy yourself a new one — that's my advice.
That's a shame, thanks for enlightening me.
Well, I've got a different one. Here...

By the way, if you end up dealing with the Hunters, keep in mind they've got excellent knives. If you manage to get one, complete satisfaction guaranteed. And when it comes to sharpening, you should go to them as well.

This one... is good. A knife like that needs proper whetstones. I could maybe run a file over it, heh-heh... You should go see the Hunters. They deal in hide work and have decent tools for the job. They should have what you need.
I'll keep that in mind. Thanks again.
Right, monster meat — that's their thing. They can't do without solid knives.
Can you sharpen a knife?

A knife? One of those the Barkeep sells? Crap, not knives. The military once brought a whole batch of defective ones into the Zone. You can't even open a tin can properly with them. Brittle steel — they dull and break fast. So toss it and buy yourself a new one — that's my advice.
That's a shame, thanks for enlightening me.
Well, I've got a different one. Here...

By the way, if you end up dealing with the Hunters, keep in mind they've got excellent knives. If you manage to get one, complete satisfaction guaranteed. And when it comes to sharpening, you should go to them as well.

This one... is good. A knife like that needs proper whetstones. I could maybe run a file over it, heh-heh... You should go see the Hunters. They deal in hide work and have decent tools for the job. They should have what you need.
I'll keep that in mind. Thanks again.
Right, monster meat — that's their thing. They can't do without solid knives.
Sylvester asked me to get the Raging Bull revolver from Vitek Raven. In return he promised an artifact recipe and something else.
Looks like you don't get many visitors here. Any profit to be had?

What profit — just scraps. Charging someone's battery, selling a few rounds, some half-decent weapons, little things. We're basically in the middle of nowhere; only hunters drop by, and even then mostly to see Pakhom about monster business, or the occasional stray, like you.

Really? This place is practically a sanatorium. Quiet, peaceful, hardly any nasty monsters — just some small toothy critters. You should post an ad on the network: come on in, we'll pamper you, feed you, give you a drink and put you to bed. Maybe people would bite and start showing up.
Our Sergeich doesn't like noise. Says it interferes with scientific work... Though it sure interferes with some folks drinking on the sly — that's for sure.
Serious people, too! And even they do that? Eh...

Sergeich himself is solid as a rock. His assistants — the postgrads — that's another story. What did you expect? We're all made of the same dough. The Zone twists anyone, reshapes them its own way. But instead of yapping, you'd be better off helping me with one little matter. You'll get something out of it, and I'll make a bit of profit.
What are you proposing?
You know a guy called Vitek Raven? Lives in the Dark Valley.
We've crossed paths. Why? Did he cross you? If so, I'm not into that kind of business.
I haven't been to that valley. Why? Did he cross you? If so, I'm not into that kind of business.
Heaven forbid, Marked One, quite the opposite. I need to ask him something — or rather, get something from him.
Can you explain properly?

Long story short... Pakhom has been dealing with him for a while and said that this Vitek can get all kinds of rare weapons. And I happen to need one particular piece, as a gift for Demian. He helps me out with... commercial matters. So I decided to thank my friend.
So he decided! And what kind of piece do you want?
A revolver — the "Raging Bull". They say it's one hell of a thunderstick. Drops a boar, a flesh, even a bloodsucker with a single shot. Makes a good gift, don't you think?
What?! Do you have any idea how much Raven will ask for it?

Marked One, please, try — I really need this. I won't leave you hanging. I've got information on how to brew a "Crystal Thorn" from a "Whirligig", a reliable recipe — tested it myself. And if you'd rather have something tangible as a reward, I can offer you a "Saiga". It's a bit worn, sure, but it drops critters just fine. Agree...
Needs a thunderstick, huh... I'll think about it.
Do you still need it?
Did you really get it? You're not joking?
No jokes. I had to sweat for it, so you won't get away with just a recipe or a used gun. You'll have to throw something extra on top. Otherwise I'll keep it for myself.

Alright, you talked me into it. I can also add a discount on charging batteries. I'll charge them for monster guts. They're easier to get in the Swamps than ammo. For free — no, don't even try to talk me into it.
Then I'll keep it for now. One hell of a fine piece.
Alright, you convinced me, take it. I envy Demian.
Great! So tell me, what do you want as a reward?
You said the recipe was proven, right? Then I'll take that. Don't feel like messing around later with repairing your pile of scrap.
Give me the "Saiga". I hope it's not completely beaten to hell?
Write down the recipe... And we're set on the battery charging — come by if you need it.
You wound me! I wouldn't offer it otherwise. Here you go... and we're set on the battery charging — come by if you need it.
If I need it, I'll come by.

\nRaven asked me to obtain an organ from a fracture — the spleen. A group of these mutants was recently spotted at Agroprom. We agreed that once I complete this task, I'll receive the Raging Bull revolver.
Raven, I need a revolver, called the "Raging Bull". Can you get one?
Let's assume I can. But I'll ask you to get something for me in return. I've received a rather specific order, so I'm actually looking for someone to handle it.
The phrase "specific order" makes me uneasy. I'd like to hear the details first.

There's a client from abroad. I think he's a bit nuts, but he pays well, so I try to fulfill his orders when possible. I don't know, maybe he's a taxidermist or something like that, but he's interested in mutant body parts and internal organs. Even ones that don't seem to have any special properties, or that the nerds pay peanuts for because they've been studied for ages. Whether he makes stuffed trophies out of them or tosses them into soup — I couldn't care less. This time he asked for a fracture's spleen. Ever heard of those freaks?
Doesn't ring a bell. Who are they?
Yeah. Even took part in a hunt for a fracture pack leader once, actually.

From a distance, they can be mistaken for a human, just badly hunched over. One arm is much longer than the other — they lean on it when walking. That same arm is what they use to smash their opponents. And they hit so hard no heavyweight boxer could dream of it. Extremely tough. Poorly affected by small-caliber rounds. Fractures almost never appear in the south of the Zone, but just the other day I was told that a group of these mutants was spotted in the southwest of Agroprom, somewhere near the border with the Swamps. Your task is to cut out the spleen from one of them and get back to me fast. I've already prepared the formalin.

Oh, I see! Then I'll skip the introduction. Fractures almost never appear in the south of the Zone, but just the other day I was told that a group of these mutants was spotted in the southwest of Agroprom, somewhere near the border with the Swamps. Your task is to cut out the spleen from one of them and get back to me fast. I've already prepared the formalin.
Formalin? What for? And what's the rush?

Ah, so you don't know about that quirk... Fractures' internal organs start rotting very quickly once the host is killed. Literally a day, sometimes a bit more — and all the guts turn into a foul, stinking sludge. That's what the "preservative" is for.\nSo, what do you say? You taking it on, or should I assign it to my guys, even though they're not too eager?
To hell with that revolver! I'm not about to rummage through rotting guts for some deranged psycho.
So I'll have about a day to deliver it. That's plenty of time, and it's not far to go. I'm in.
Watch your words, Marked One. The Zone likes to ruin the plans of overly self-confident stalkers.
Raven, get the revolver ready. I brought you the fracture's spleen.
That's very good that you brought it. The client already managed to message me asking to hurry up. I hope the spleen hasn't rotted yet? Hold on, I'll open the jar of formalin...
Ugh... take it already. I get that money doesn't smell, but not in this case.
Alright, stop grumbling. Your revolver, and as a bonus — some ammo for it. Here you go.
Now that's a gun, all right...
The Barkeep says you ran into his friend? Can you tell me where to find him?

A friend... of the Barkeep?! Maybe I did. Only things aren't so clean with that "friend." I've heard there's a debt hanging over him. So the question is whether he's really the Barkeep's friend at all. I can tell you where I saw him, sure — but if that stalker's being looked for over debts, maybe there's something in it for me too?
Doesn't look like the Barkeep's trying to shake him down for money. That'd be a very different conversation... He even seems worried.

Seems or doesn't — time will tell. I'm not asking for much. We've got a problem with booze. You know how it is. Can't find decent vodka — all counterfeits. A hunter dropped by the other day and said they're distilling moonshine in the Gut, at the sawmill — pure distillate. Bring a couple of jars, just to sample. Prosha, the local butcher, handles the bottling for them. Then we'll talk about the Barkeep's friend.
Someone already told me about that drink... Alright, we'll sort your problem out. You'll have to wait, though.
I'll wait, sure — but that friend might just slip away.
Still interested in the booze?
You brought it?! Now that's doing us a solid.
Don't reach for it yet. Remember our deal?
Easy there, Marked One, everything's still on.
Just don't drink yourself blind.
Don't worry, we know our limits. So, about that stalker...
And what about my artifact? The one I left in exchange for the suit.

What? Yes, yes... the artifact. You see, there's a situation... We were forced to urgently transport a batch of artifacts outside the Zone, including the specimen you left, but we already have a suitable replacement. However, it does require opening the casing first. Please accept our apologies for this minor inconvenience. So, are you returning the suit?
Here it is, take it.
You know, I actually still need it. I'll return it later.
Very well. And this is for you. Once again, please accept my apologies for how this turned out...
Sakharov asked me to deal with a controller at the Yantar plant. He promised an experimental suit as a reward
Professor, did you want to ask something?

You see, Marked One, after you disabled that ill-fated installation, we decided to send a research group onto the plant grounds. At the moment, the emitter is operating in a safe mode, but another problem has arisen... A controller was spotted in the central building, where the entrance to the underground laboratory is located. Alas, among my colleagues there are no brave souls like yourself. They cannot handle such a dangerous opponent, and they do not wish to try... which I understand. Could you somehow resolve this problem? Not for free, of course.
What about Duty, the military... You have an agreement with them.

That is true. They agreed to guard only our bunker and the surrounding area, but after one unfortunate incident they categorically refuse to go to the plant. So, will you help science? As a reward I can offer a very good suit. This particular specimen was developed at a research institute and has been tested under the most extreme conditions.
A suit, you say... I will try to resolve your problem.
No, Professor, a controller is very dangerous. I'm not sure I can handle it.
And bring the hand of that creature. For our work, we require a body part of this mutant.
That's a shame. I was counting on you.
First you ask, then you almost order... Fine, I'll cut off an arm for science.
I await good news.
I'm about the controller on the plant grounds.
Forgive me, there is a lot of work... Which controller?

Professor, you asked me to solve the problem, and I did. The controller is dead. It's relatively quiet on the plant grounds now. Your assistants can safely go there and do their work. I think they can handle a couple of snorks on their own.
Ah, that. Well then — thank you, that's one less headache. I believe I promised you an experimental suit. Or did I forget something again?
No, the suit exactly.
You were also supposed to bring the hand of that mutant.
Here it is, take it.
Damn it, in the commotion I forgot to cut it off.
Then receive your reward. And thank you once again.
So how are you holding up, Wolf? Everything alright?
Little by little... If I asked you for a favor, could you help me out?
Help you? How so?
Recently I sent a messenger into the Gut, but he's been gone a long time now. I'd go myself, but I ought to stay in the village — bandits might show up again.
You're suggesting I take a trip?

Don't drop everything just for this, but if it's not too much trouble and you're heading that way — have a look. Maybe something happened... Maybe he went on a bender... If you're in the Gut, walk around, ask the hunters if anyone's seen Vasya. He's got a distinctive gun too — a TOZ, side-by-side, sixty-six. Not many people have those. Check a few houses... buildings, just in case. Maybe you'll manage to find a trail.
If I'm in those parts, I'll ask about Vasya, if I remember.
Go look for him yourself! There's enough people to guard the village without you!
Then tie a knot... to help you remember. Heh-heh...
Hey there, how's things?
You haven't been to the Gut by any chance?
I've been thinking... I'm not going to find your messenger. The Gut is huge, nobody there will say a thing.
Still... have a look around there if it's on your way, maybe you'll find some kind of trail.
Damn it... Alright. I'll walk around, take a look.

I was... Looks like I found your messenger — or rather, his corpse. At the farmstead closer to the railway bridge, I ran into a bandit ambush. I made it out fine, but your messenger... the guy got unlucky.
A corpse? Didn't you find anything distinctive there?
He had some strange scribble on him. Here, take a look. Some numbers, abbreviations — BO, KK, NZ... some kind of cipher, yeah? And there's a note at the end about a shotgun.
Nothing. Didn't really look around much. Oh... there was another piece of paper... where did I put it?! Hold on, I'll find it and bring it.
Well, well... That's him! His scrawl... Damn it all! I had a feeling it was a setup! Shouldn't have sent him alone. Someone tipped them off, no doubt about it.
So what's that strange scribble about?
What it says isn't important anymore. Not your problem... Here's some buckshot for your trouble.
Alright then... Just asking.
\nWolf asks me to find his messenger who went into the Gut and disappeared. He suggested asking the hunters.
Yurik got himself into trouble at the Garbage, asking for help.
Well, well! Our traveler finally shows up... So what happened to him this time?

Lost to some Baldy at the Bar. The debt's not huge, but obviously it has to be paid. He made a run for it out of the Bar, but the boys caught up with him at the Garbage, shaking him down like a punching bag. And Yurik's got nothing to his name but some washed-out pants.
Marked One, why are you being so kind all of a sudden? You came running all the way from the Garbage just for me? Who is Yurik to you?
Just felt sorry for the guy, total greenhorn. I stepped in, promised the boys I'd pay up for him, but my own pockets aren't exactly bursting either. So...
Ahh... You should've started with that. Instead of "Yurik's in trouble, help him"... Sounds like the debt's on you now. Creditors breathing down your neck?
They are...
So what do they want?
They'll accept either a simple artifact or ten thousand in local currency.

That really isn't much, but... Here's what we'll do. Beyond the embankment, by the road, there's an overturned truck lying there—you've probably seen it? One "hero" from the local youngsters decided to poke around it the other day. Someone filled his head with the idea that artifacts are drawn to large metal objects. Funny thing is, he actually did find some kind of art nearby. But the fool didn't know the radiation near that truck is heavy, and he didn't have a counter on him. Long story short, he managed to grab the art and stash it in his backpack, then suddenly felt real bad—barely crawled out of the radioactive hotspot. Lucky for him, a couple of experienced stalkers were coming back from a run, hauling loot to Sid. They spotted the kid, jabbed him with anti-rad, and dragged him to the village. Now to the point: the rookie ditched the backpack with the artifact right there by the truck, thinking it was what made him sick. If you get it, it's yours—no change needed. And don't forget to stock up on anti-rads from Sidorovich.
That really isn't much, but... You got yourselves into this mess, you deal with it yourselves.
Yeah, those rookies... Thanks for the tip, Wolf.
Hey there, stalker. Folks call me the Marked One. And you are?
Same to you. Name's Ivan.
Don't think I've seen you around here before. Though, to be fair, I myself haven't been here long either. You a local, or just passing through?
We're all just passing through here... I drop by sometimes, out of old habit. To dump some loot with Sidorovich, have a bit of vodka with the lads... relax, basically. You should sit down with us.
I see you've got an unusual suit on you. Where'd you get it?
This is a suit from the former Clear Sky group. Ever heard of them? They call me Sky because I used to be part of that group.
I was told that the leaders of that group were looking for a stalker by the name of Strelok.
No, haven't heard of it. Like I said, I'm new around here.

So why the sudden interest in that old story? Yeah, they were looking for him. They even hired a mercenary to hunt Strelok. I had nothing to do with it myself — it was Lebedev and Kalancha who got it into their heads that the Zone was expanding because of Strelok. That's why they were gathering every bit of information they could find on him.
If you've got questions, come by.
And where is that information? Did it survive anywhere? And by the way, what kind of mercenaries are they? Lone guns-for-hire, working for whoever pays, or do they have some kind of headquarters?

I don't know. I don't care who they are, what they want, or where they're from. All I care about is not ending up in their sights. And if anything from Clear Sky did survive, it's probably at our old base, in the Swamps. We left that place together with Lebedev almost a year ago. Ïðàâäà, a boar tore me up pretty bad with its tusk, and I ended up lying around here for almost two months. Spent all my loot. When I finally got back on my feet, I went to the base, but there was nobody there anymore.
Could you take me to your base?

No, I'm not going back there — had enough of wading through mud. And the Swamps are poor pickings anyway. Hardly any artifacts, but tons of critters — small, nasty ones. Still, alright, I'll show you the way. Not for free, of course. I want to try my luck again — head north, look for a path to the center of the Zone. You toss me some ammo for my AKM, regular stuff is fine, about ten packs, and I'll point you toward the Swamps. No hard feelings — the beasts up north are no joke.
I'll think about it. Ammo's something I need myself, especially that caliber...
Just don't think too long... I'm heading out on another run one of these days, burned through my supplies here.
Listen, Ivan, I wanted to ask about the Clear Sky group.
About what exactly?
I was told that the group's leaders were looking for a stalker by the name of Strelok.

Yeah, they were. They even hired a mercenary to hunt Strelok. I had nothing to do with it myself — it was Lebedev and Kalancha who got it into their heads that the Zone was expanding because of Strelok. That's why they were gathering every bit of information they could find on him...

And where is that information? Did it survive anywhere? And by the way, what kind of mercenaries are they? Lone guns-for-hire, working for whoever they want, or do they have some kind of headquarters?

I don't know. I'm not interested in who they are, why they exist, or where they're from. All that matters to me is not ending up in their sights. And if anything from Clear Sky did survive, it's probably at our former base, in the Swamps. We left that place together with Lebedev almost a year ago. Though, a boar tore me up pretty bad with its tusk, and I lay around here for almost two months. Spent all my loot. When I finally got back on my feet, I went to the base, but there was nobody there anymore.
Could you take me to your base, to the Swamps?

No, I'm not going back there, I'm sick of trudging through mud. And the Swamps are poor when it comes to profit. Few artifacts, but tons of critters — small and nasty. Still, alright, I'll show you the way. Not for free, of course. I want to try my luck again — head out in search of a path to the center of the Zone. You toss me some ammo for my AKM, regular stuff is fine, about ten packs preferably, and I'll show you the road to the Swamps. No offense — the beasts up north are serious.
I'll think about it, ammo's something I need myself, especially that caliber...
Just don't overthink it... I'll be heading out on another raid one of these days, burned through my supplies here.

Ivan Sky promises to show the way to the former Clear Sky base in exchange for 10 packs of 7.62 caliber ammo. As it turned out, they once had some involvement with Strelok. Perhaps it will be possible to find some leads in their camp.
Listen, I'm here about the road to the Swamps.
The road? Ah! You mean the Clear Sky base?\nWell? Did you get the ammo? Three hundred rounds, like we agreed?
Yes, of course. Here it is.
Hmm, not quite.
Excellent! Sorry I couldn't help you just like that... I ran myself dry, and then you... showed up. You've got to understand... No hard feelings.
Ivan! Get to the point.

Alright then, head into the ravine right behind the village. There you'll see a section of barbed-wire fencing knocked down by a fallen tree. That's where you go. A path starts there — after a couple of kilometers it'll lead you to the Southern Farmstead. From there, head west, past the old church, by the guard tower, to the next farmstead. After that you'll either find your way yourself or ask the local old-timers.
Alright, I'll try to find it.
Ivan, I wanted to ask you about your shotgun.

You like it? I do too... I traded for it from some stalker over at the Garbage. Had a few artifacts on me, so I went for it. Solid little piece, handy against all kinds of critters. So what's your interest?
I'll be honest — I've been promised some very important information for that shotgun. Maybe we can strike a deal?
You want to bargain for it?
If you don't ask for too much... I won't say no.

Hmm... I won't try to cash in. I paid artifacts for it myself. Let's do it this way: you give me a couple of good artifacts, second-tier ones, and I'll hand over this piece to you in good faith. And I'll need a weapon in return too. Get me a rifle — a proper one — chambered for 7.62! I blew all my loot on booze, had a hell of a time celebrating here with the guys. So what do you say? Deal?
Well then... we have a deal. Take the artifacts and the rifle.
I don't have them on me yet, I'll bring them soon.
Excellent! Take it...
Ivan Sky promises to hand over the shotgun that belonged to Nut, a gopnik from the Garbage, in exchange for two second-tier artifacts and a rifle chambered for 7.62 caliber ammo.
Ivan, I'm here about your shotgun.
Didn't we already agree on everything? Two second-tier artifacts plus a good assault rifle, and you become the owner of this marvel.
Yeah, I remember, I remember. Here are the artifacts and the assault rifle.
I don't have them on me yet, I'll bring them soon.
Excellent! Take it...
Good to see you, Ivan Sky.
Good to see you too, Marked One.
Found the road to the center of the Zone, or what? Care to share?
I found my own. You go look for yours.
Hmm... Everyone has their own path, right?
I'm here about the briefcase with the kompromat.
You found a similar case?! No way!
You took your sweet time, my friend. That little case has sailed. Now I'll have to keep the capital bigwigs happy. You know what their appetites are like?!
Your call.
Sidorovich, quit whining, you won't go broke. I'm giving you the briefcase. Might come in handy again.

Looks like the same one. Excellent... We should see this through to the end. I'll give Kuznetsov a call, he'll arrange a courier on the spot. You come up to their barracks at night, from the fence side. Where the concrete slabs are.
I was really counting on you, Marked One, by the way.
Can you be more specific?

Alright, listen carefully: if you look at the checkpoint from the road, there's an APC with thermal vision standing right in the middle — best stay clear of that. But you can slip through on the left side. Stick as close to the barbed wire as you can, there's a gap near a fallen tree. Climb through it and you'll see a fence on the right, a guard tower with a sentry. Where the fence ends, there are several concrete slabs piled up — that's where a soldier will be waiting for you once it gets properly dark. You'll make the exchange right there.\nBring the briefcase straight to me... Come by in the morning, I'm not young enough to lose sleep over this. And Marked One — please, don't make any noise.
There's the question of compensation. That case didn't come cheap for me. I'd like to be reimbursed.
We'll settle up later. Grab some vodka for the soldier and get moving.
Brought the briefcase with the kompromat.
Well done! Everything go quietly?
Smooth as butter... Met up, had a drink, grabbed a bite, talked about life, then went our separate ways. Take the briefcase.

You really did me a favor, Marked One. Though of course you can't live on "thanks" alone. So here — take ten... no, eight thousand tugriks, and we're square!\nLet's see what we've got here... Well, well... A tricky little lock... Aha!\nHere's what's shaping up... According to my information, besides the kompromat, this case also contains some documents about the military's dealings in the Zone and all that. The Barkeep has a sharp lad who can crack this briefcase open. Take this box to him. Looks like we'll get some useful information out of it. You might get something out of it too. You in?
Sidorovich, I thought we were talking about your godfather. Remember?

Ah! Right, of course! Alright, listen up. My godfather, Mikhalych, settled down in an abandoned town — Limansk. According to him, there's an installation there that might be clearing people's minds. That's what one smart guy told him, anyway. Bottom line — when you get to Limansk, you'll talk it over on the spot. Give him my regards.
Limansk? Where's that?

A small town just beyond the Red Forest. I've never been there myself. Stalkers say there's a direct route, through the Army Warehouses. Though mercenaries have settled in there now. Ask them about it... As they say, the tongue will get you where you need to go. Got it?
I think I got it.
So what do you say? Shall we come to an agreement about the box? Will you take it?
Sidorovich, you said it yourself — you scratch my back, I scratch yours. Or what?

Ah! By the way!\nWhy didn't I suggest this right away. There's a nerd working in the Swamps, nearby. Once, after a bit of this and that, he bragged that he could dig up a dossier on anyone here in the Zone. Claims he's got connections in the authorities.
I don't get it — what does that have to do with me?

Looks like you really smacked your head good and hard. I'll spell it out for the especially gifted:\nFingerprints can tell you who you are! Come on, think. If you're in their database, you'll get a hint about your name and why you came into the Zone. Got it or not?
Now I get it. Who's this nerd, and where exactly?

There's a small military post on the southern edge of the Swamps. Almost at the Zone's border. That's where the nerd hangs around. Studying something along his nerdy line. You'll find him if you want to.\nSo, are you taking the briefcase to the Bar?
Alright, I'll take it.
Just don't lose it.
Sidorovich, did you call for me again?
Oh, Marked One! You were looking for a stalker by the nickname Ghost, right? Found him or what?
No, not yet. Why?
Hmm, well, here's the deal. A mutual acquaintance of ours, Kuznetsov, tossed me an idea on how to smooth things over with the new battalion commander.
So you want to fix your problems at someone else's expense? Enough already, stop trying to ride on my back.

You listen first and don't interrupt. So... About a month ago, maybe more, that same Ghost volunteered to escort a group of scientists and the soldiers guarding them to some northern point in the Zone. The group vanished. Never checked in. No news since. The current battalion commander decided to organize a search. Looks like he got chewed out from above if he's finally moving. But you understand — charging blindly deep into the Zone, and with unprepared troops at that, means losing them and getting yourself killed too. Those damn soldiers only know how to shout "Attention!" and "At ease!". For raids like that, you need experience.
Get to the point already.

You're an experienced stalker. Need supplies, proper gear? Yeah? And you want to find Ghost too... Whether you find that group or not is secondary. What matters is you'll learn something about Ghost, and at the same time we'll do the battalion commander a favor by agreeing to look for those people. And if you do find any traces, you'll earn respect and gratitude from all sides. You get it?
If the army can't handle it, how am I supposed to help? Let them deal with it themselves.
What do you need from me?
Then we'll look for someone else.

I told the commander that there's an experienced guide who can track down the group's trail. You need to go to the checkpoint. You'll find the deputy battalion commander there and talk it over with him. Just don't show off your weapons there, you know how it is. I'll warn the guys, sure, but soldiers are jumpy — they might open fire if they see your arsenal. And don't go there late at night either, they'll shoot first and won't ask your name. Once you sort things out with him, come back to me. Tell me how it went. Off you go.
I talked to the battalion commander.
How did they receive you?
Everything's fine. He gave me some gear, food, medicine, and sent me off to the middle of nowhere... I need to go to Limansk, to your godfather, Mikhalych.
That's not close... But you're used to it. You're a seasoned guy, go on.

Since when did that old geezer start getting along with the military? What a sly one. Well then, since you're heading that way, maybe you could pass a little gift to my godfather? As a favor, so to speak.
No idea about contacts — you sort that out yourselves. And if it's anything heavy, I'm not carrying it. I've already got a ton of gear to haul. The road there isn't short.

You're a seasoned guy, you'll manage. And you won't have to strain yourself either. Remember that container with the artifact you brought me? The one Butterfingers lost. There was a special artifact in it. And my godfather's a bit... obsessed with that sort of thing. Do the man a favor, pass the artifact along to him. Who knows, maybe something will come your way too.
Decided to grease your godfather's palm? Alright, but without the container. I've got my own.
Your godfather will manage without a gift... Crafty bastard.
Suit yourself, take it. I'll let Mikhalych know to expect a courier.
Your loss.
Sidorovich asked me to deliver a rare artifact as a gift to Mikhalych. Something should come of it.
Let the battalion commander know there's news for him.

Maybe I should snap to attention too? Not even a hello or a please. Look at you, found yourself a commander already. Five minutes talking to soldiers and you've picked up their habits... Or maybe you're one of them, military? Why not? You've got the posture, you shoot well, and all that other stuff. Mug like a seasoned soldier fits you just fine. Even your voice has changed. Maybe you really are military, or from some similar outfit. What's got you thinking?
I don't remember... But that's not what this is about right now. Please inform the battalion commander.
It's better when a man shows some respect. Did you at least find out what they were interested in?
I did, I did... I'd rather not spread it around. It concerns the missing expedition. I need to meet with him.
Then get moving to the checkpoint, they're waiting for you. Asked about you five times a day. Just don't rattle your weapons, I remind you.
Mikhailych, there's a little present for you, from your godfather.
From Sidor?! And what is it, a pood of sea salt?
Why salt of all things? He sent an artifact. Said you're really into them... you know.
An artifact is good. But salt wouldn't hurt either. Wanted to take a bath, warm up my bones. They say it helps you relax. Heart, blood vessels, nervous system — everything's at the limit.
You even have a bathtub here? Some people sure live well...
I'm joking, but still — you want to live like a proper person. So what did he send?
Said it's a very rare... specimen.
Don't make things up. Sidor's never known words like that. But it's a nice trinket... When you see that old rat, give him my thanks. And this is for you — for cheering up an old man.
I checked out the entrance to the underground. I think this blockage can be cleared.
You think so? Yeah, right... Go on and clear it, what's it to me.
If you gather about a dozen guys, it can be done in half a day. Assign your boys to the job.
Clear the blockage? What, my boys are Tajiks or something?
I get it... I'll try to compensate you as best I can.

Compensate, you say? And what am I supposed to tell the brotherhood — that they're busting their backs for some random schmuck? And how do you think they'll look at me after that? I do business with you 'cause it don't break our code. But the boys ain't gonna slave "for some uncle." That's not our suit. So either clear it yourself or find someone else. There's plenty of all kinds of folks roaming around here. Got it?

Compensate, you say? And what was all that shooting about, huh? Some guy came running to me with his eyes popping out... You didn't happen to lay some crooks out at the factory, did you? Alright, I'll smooth it over. Those lads figured they could live without Papa Borov, by their own rules. Serves 'em right! But I'm not giving you my people to clear that blockage. Today you're "compensating" some, tomorrow you'll go after mine, huh? Bottom line — I'm closing my eyes to this little "incident," but not a single crew is gonna help you with that blockage. Clear it yourself or find someone else. There's plenty of different folks roaming around here. Got it?
I got it. Only thing is, your people settled in at the factory. If I find someone, how's that gonna work?

Mine, yeah — but not mine anymore. Those lads figured they could live without Papa Borov. Wanted freedom. They're gathering their own pack of all sorts of nutjobs. So if something happens to them, I won't be losing any sleep over it. I'd squash 'em myself... but I can't. That's the whole picture. You catch my drift?
Yeah, I get it, I get it. Only those crooks, as you put it, had it coming! They paid for their lawlessness.
Got it, got it.
Borov, got a question for you, you mind?
Ha! Sometimes you talk like you ain't some gray suit, but black as night. Go on, spit it out.

I checked the entrance to the underground. There's a blockage, sure, but it's not that solid — could be cleared in half a day if there were helpers. You wouldn't send your boys on the job, would you? I'd compensate somehow...
I actually wanted to ask about your night scares. Still bothering you?

Compensate, huh... It ain't really kosher for drifters to sweat like regular laborers, but... alright, let's do it this way. You, Marked One, you're a straight-up kid, show respect to the brotherhood, helped sort out our messes too. Help us deal with one more bit of trouble, and I'll give the word for the punks to get busy with your job.

You could say that. Half the deck's already pushing weight during the day, and keeping watch at night. Some folks are stirring the pot, saying we should bail from here. We've got one trump hideout far up north, as a backup. If things get real bad, we'll have to haul ass there.
So what's the trouble?

Yeah, you're really pressed. I've thought it over, I'll try to help. So it all happens at night, huh? Gotta admit, my knees are already knocking, but curiosity's got the better of me. Let's see what kind of glowing ball's taken up behind the gas station.

Some crap's gotten into the habit of flying around at night behind the gas station. Looks like a glowing ball, kind of translucent. And sometimes a flame just flares up in the middle of the clearing, all by itself. The boys on watch are totally on edge — say this dread just rolls over you, chills you right to the tailbone. And they ain't bullshitting, looks like. I've been sleeping like crap myself, seeing all kinds of stuff half-asleep. And Veiny was yapping the other day that he heard voices around midnight... Devilry, basically. You stalkers are used to this kinda voodoo. You'll take a look, yeah? See what's there? Think you can wipe this filth out or chase it off? My goons'll clear your blockage in no time then.
At night, huh? My knees are already knocking, but curiosity's getting the better of me. Alright, let's see what kind of glowing ball it is.
I'm not ready to jump in right away. Need to think it through.

I made a deal with Borov that he would send his people to clear the blockage at the entrance to X-18 if I helped rid his gang of the strange entities that fly around near their base at night and terrify its inhabitants.
You can sleep easy again, I took care of your night nightmares.
Yeah? Fo' real? Damn, nice work! So what was it? What kinda balls?
Those mysterious balls turned out to be... well, just another of the Zone's spawn, nothing special.

Would you look at that! "Nothing special," he says! Alright then, you're tight with our brotherhood now, which means it ain't beneath the boys to play regular workhorses for once. I'll send a construction crew to the factory right away, and I'll drop you a note when they're done.\nBy the way! I figure this is something useful for you to know. Word came in from some punks who dropped by Mongol to throw bones. They were planning to crawl into some underground too, but it didn't pan out for 'em at first. Supposedly, in those labs, before they bolted, the eggheads pumped in some hardcore gas. Without special suits with a closed breathing cycle, there's jack shit to do in there. Keep that in mind.
Much obliged, I'll be waiting for your signal.
I received your message, Professor. What did you want?
Marked One, I am glad to see you in good health. Do you remember our conversation about the scientist you found on Radar?
The one who survived the helicopter crash? Prikhodko, if I remember his name correctly?

Yes, yes. You see, that time I was not completely frank with you. In fact, a total of five helicopters were involved in that operation. One of them carried Prikhodko's group, the others had personnel from a departmental institute and the military. Our curators insisted on mandatory scientific support for this mission, and we could not refuse. They also took full responsibility for the financial and technical provision of the expedition. As you already know, it failed. Not a single chopper returned to base. Moreover, the fate of three helicopters is still not known for certain. Indirect evidence suggests that they made emergency landings at different points in the Zone. All passengers and crew members, except for Prikhodko, are listed as missing, but to be honest, they most likely perished. The higher-ups did not raise much of a fuss until I recently informed them about the survivor you discovered.
I don't understand what you're getting at.

It appears that the leadership initially deemed it impractical to allocate resources for a search operation, however your success convinced them otherwise. Now they demand that I organize additional searches, since, in their opinion, I have already managed to assemble such a qualified operative for the Radar mission. That is, of course, you, Marked One. First of all, I wanted to involve General Voronin's fighters, as we quite often cooperate with his group. However, it proved impossible to contact him through the old channels and, as it turned out later, there is no longer any point in doing so. I honestly do not know whom else to turn to. I need reliable, proven, experienced people; the matter is delicate. Broadening the circle of those in the know is highly undesirable. At the same time, the management is putting pressure on me daily, threatening to cut funding for my project if I take no action. And that would mean the complete collapse of my scientific career.
Let's not beat around the bush, Professor. You want me to take care of this?
You understood correctly! Your skills have allowed you to reach such corners of the Zone that other stalkers can only dream of visiting.
Better they keep dreaming than get eaten by monsters or torn to shreds by an anomaly. Or worse — join those mumbling wretches wandering around Radar.

What I mean, Marked One, is that your knowledge and your ability to penetrate the most hidden places of the Zone give you a high chance of completing this mission without any particular... complications.

Oh, you've really wrapped it up nicely, Professor... Just say it outright — you don't really care what happens to me. Who am I to you? Just another stalker, a bit luckier than the rest. If not me, you'll find another, a third...

Marked One, why so harsh? I hold you in very high regard. And I turned to you because I am confident in your integrity. You are better suited for this task than anyone else. Think about my words. Only, if possible, I would like to receive your answer no later than within a day, otherwise I will have to look for another... contractor. Please understand my position: too much is at stake for me.
Maybe I'm not right... I'll think about it.
Professor, I've thought over your proposal.
Do you agree?
I agree, but first I'd like to discuss the terms.
No, I don't want to risk it unnecessarily.

As I understand it, first and foremost you want to know the size of the reward? Well, that is perfectly businesslike, in the spirit of the times, so to speak. In that case, make your own proposal. I will try, as far as possible, to satisfy your demands.

I am interested in modificates transformed from artifacts of the "Dummy" class. The methods of obtaining them, to be precise. I think it would be fair if I rummaged through your database and chose the recipe I need myself, from the categories up to and including absolutes. If nothing suitable turns up, then so be it — I am willing to accept payment in foreign currency. I believe two thousand dollars in bearer's checks would be equivalent to a rare recipe, wouldn't you agree? And you will also reimburse the consumables I spend during the upcoming mission. Does that work?

The terms are accepted. Then let us not waste any more time and proceed straight to business.\nUnfortunately, I do not have precise reference points for the search, as I already mentioned, but approximate areas have nevertheless been established. One helicopter should be located in the southern part of the Swamps, the second in the eastern part of the Tesla Zone, the third in the north of the Ivankovsky District Center. In addition to determining the exact coordinates of the helicopters, you will need to inspect them for the presence of "black boxes," which recorded not only the data of the helicopters' flight systems, but also the readings of other scientific equipment installed on each of them. There may be extremely valuable information there. I propose starting with the Swamps. And please do not delay, I ask you. I am expected to provide a report to the higher authorities.
They've waited this long, they can wait a bit more. Alright, alright, I got it. I'll try to handle it as soon as possible.
Sakharov needs the "black box" from the helicopter in the Swamps.
I managed to locate the helicopter in the Swamps and retrieve the "black box" from it.
Then please hand it over at once. And send the coordinates to my tablet.
Yes, of course. Here you go.

This is exactly what we need, judging by the markings. It was not in vain that I entrusted you with this task, Marked One. I will now credit your account so that you can replenish your stock of consumables, as we agreed. You will be able to choose what you need from our exchange fund yourself.
Yeah, certainly. Where to next? To the Tesla Zone?

Do not rush. I would like you to head to the Dark Valley first. Another helicopter crashed there recently as well. Although this incident is unrelated to the Radar expedition, it occurred to me that the authorities would not mind digging into the flight recorder of that aircraft too. The crash site coordinates are known to us. It is south of the old factory, in the hilly terrain lying east of the large swamp.
What? The deal was to search for three helicopters! That's not how business is done!

An extra "black box" will serve as a sort of bonus for the armchair intellectuals. For you, however, the bonus will be any, as you put it, artifact creation recipe from the line commonly referred to as "unique." So, does that motivate you to take a little detour?

You are quite the adventurer, Professor... Very well, then here is a countercondition: if there is no suitable recipe in your database, I will take an additional thousand dollars from you in a bearer's check. Get it however you like. And I am heading to the Dark Valley. We'll see if anything can be extracted from that helicopter.
Sakharov needs the "black box" from the helicopter in the Dark Valley.
I managed to retrieve the "black box" from the helicopter in the Dark Valley.
Then please hand it over at once.
Here you go. It's in decent shape. You can even make out the letters and numbers.

Very good. I had concerns that the recorder might be badly damaged. I will now credit your account so that you can replenish your stock of consumables, as we agreed. And now, regarding your reward. Please, choose a recipe.
I am interested in this one — "Battery" from "Snow".
I am interested in this one — "Jumper" from "Springboard".
I am interested in this one — "Electro-Beads" from "Snow".
I am interested in this one — "Spray Can" from "Witch's Jelly".
I am interested in this one — "Airship" from "Snow".
I am interested in this one — "Eye" from "Snow".
I am interested in this one — "Gorgon Jellyfish" from "Witch's Jelly".
I don't see anything suitable here. Let's have the check, as agreed.
Please provide the communication code of your PDA so that I can send you the information you are interested in.
Here you are. I had to pay for its processing out of my own savings. You see how much I value our cooperation?
Uh... and where do I look at that?

Let me do everything myself. Done. Please note, you are the only stalker to whom I have ever granted access to our database of artifact transmutation transformations. You see how much I value our cooperation?
Deeply touched. Let's move on. Now it's the Tesla Zone for me, as I understand it? A nasty place, I must say.
I have no doubt about your words. But since you have been there before and returned alive, I dare hope that luck will accompany you this time as well.
Professor, do you have any idea what happened there in that "Tesla" Zone? The ground looks as if it was turned inside out. Something burst out from underground there — but what?
The events that took place there are unknown to me. Attempts by research groups to penetrate the area generally ended in failure. You yourself say it — a dreadful place.
That's true. Alright then, no point in dragging this out any longer... I'm off.
Sakharov needs the "black box" from the helicopter in the Tesla Zone.
I managed to locate the helicopter in the Tesla Zone and retrieve the "black box" from it.
Then please hand it over at once. And send the coordinates to my tablet.
Yes, of course. Here you go.

This is exactly what we need, judging by the markings. It was not in vain that I entrusted you with this task, Marked One. I will now credit your account so that you can replenish your stock of consumables, as we agreed.
The last one is in the district center, right? No more unpleasant surprises, I hope?
That is correct, this is the final stage of the mission.
Listen, Professor, why were they scattered all over the Zone in the first place? According to your story, they were flying to a single point.
I would very much like to know the answer to that question myself. I hope the "black boxes" you found will shed some light on this mystery.
Then I'm off to the district center. I'd like to wrap all this up as soon as possible.
Sakharov needs the "black box" from the helicopter in the Ivankovsky District Center.
I managed to locate the helicopter in the Ivankovsky District Center and retrieve the "black box" from it.
Then please hand it over at once. And send the coordinates to my tablet.
Yes, of course. Here you go.

Excellent! You handled this extremely difficult task masterfully, Marked One. I will now credit your account so that you can replenish your stock of consumables, as we agreed. Now please, choose your reward.
Let's take a look at the modificate recipes.
Let's take a look at the mesomodificate recipes.
Let's take a look at the hypermodificate recipes.
Let's take a look at the absolute recipes.
Here is the list... Which of these interests you?
"Droplet of Soul".
"Electra's Tears".
"Grandma's Beads".
"Fire Dummy".
"Porcupine".
"Steel Kolobok".
"Hide".
"Fiery Soul".
"Fire Tears".
"Great Grandmother's Beads".
"Bright Dummy".
"Electric Porcupine".
"Titanium Kolobok".
"Scales".
"Crystal Soul".
"Chimera's Tears".
"Burer's Grandmother's Beads".
"Moon Dummy".
"Snotty Porcupine".
"Diamond Kolobok".
"Armor".
"Crystal Bengal Soul".
"Giant's Tears".
"Burer's Great Grandmother's Beads".
"Pudding".
"Stone Porcupine".
"Giant's Younger Brother".
"Controller Scalp".
Nothing. Let's return to the category list.
No, none of this works for me. Professor, I think I'd rather take the money.
Are you absolutely certain?
As you wish. On such an occasion, I do not mind paying out of my own pocket. Thank you very much, Marked One!
Yes.
No, let's return to the category list.
The information has been sent. Thank you very much, Marked One!
Choose.
I still have a few questions...
Forgive me, Marked One, but all questions later. I must attend to the transfer of the flight recorders. There are other urgent matters as well. No offense, but we will talk another time.
I understand... not saying goodbye.
\nSakharov asks you to clarify the fate of the scientific reconnaissance group in the Red Forest. You should search in the old mine working near the entrance to the reserve.
I found traces of your group in the Red Forest.
As I understand it, no one survived?
That's right. Who even advised them to set up a base in that place? It's a nest of snorks and poltergeists. Those creatures, as I've noticed, are very fond of such spots.

Regrettable... lately we have been losing our colleagues far too often. Well then, thank you for clearing things up. Please accept medical kits and a small sum credited to your personal account as a token of gratitude. It should help you out.
Contact me if you need to find someone else. I'll help however I can.
\nSemyonov asks you to find an "emerald" artifact for him. He promises a good reward.
Listen, have you heard about "emerald" artifacts?

Ha... not only have I heard of them, I've even held them in my hands. Ghost brought a few from somewhere. That was back when he and Vasilyev were getting ready to search for the entrance to an underground laboratory.
Did he say where he got them?

No. He's not a talkative type. These "emeralds" are very rare in their own right. Their properties are poorly studied. Whether the Zone produces them or they are the result of artificial transformation, I cannot say for sure. Ask around at the Bar, talk to Tooth. He has all kinds of information. Maybe he knows something about the "emeralds" too.\nIf you happen to come across such an artifact, bring it to me. I promise a very good reward.

That's for later... Here in the Gut, I spoke with one of yours — Petrov was his name. According to him, three "emerald" artifacts assembled together can move a person somewhere downward, by several meters. It's just not clear how... What do you think about that?

What am I supposed to think? The Zone — that says it all. Who really knows anything about it for certain? Teleportation here is, you could say, a fairly ordinary phenomenon. Just recall the Bungees. So go ahead and try it, why not?! Just before experimenting, make sure there's some space below you, and not just solid earth. Otherwise you might end up burying yourself alive.
Yeah... It's clear that nothing is clear. I'll think about your proposal regarding the "emerald."
I managed to find an "emerald" artifact.
Whoa! Will you donate it to science… I mean, trade it?
You said this artifact is very rare. What can you offer for it?
I have a recipe for one modificate, it's called "Porcupine". There's also some information about a stash with artifacts.
What kind of stash? And what artifacts are there?

When Ghost was scouting a route to the laboratory, he complained that he blundered onto the factory grounds at a bad moment. A whole pack of snorks came out of nowhere. He had to leave part of his gear and a container with artifacts there. Had to make his escape light.
A container, you say? Wouldn't it be the one with the "emeralds"? Although… how did they get into the laboratory then, if the artifacts were left at the factory?

That's a big question — where they ended up. No one has seen Vasilyev or Ghost since then. He left the "emeralds" here before the reconnaissance, and those artifacts were meant for Sakharov as trade goods. Ghost always had very fine specimens. Stalkers rarely bring in ones like that. In the end, he had to take some of his gear on credit, since the artifacts stayed at the factory.
Artifacts come and go. Better hand over the recipe.
So where should I look for that container?
Then write it down, it makes a very good modificate.

Ghost said that by the far wall, on the right if you're facing in from the entrance, there's a green construction trailer. That's where he left it.\nIt's probably still lying there. After that incident, as far as I know, no one dared to poke around the factory grounds.
About your moonshine.
Ah, it's you, Marked One. There's moonshine, but no containers. Bring me five empty jars and you'll get one cherished full one. Heh-heh.
Five jars… That was the deal.
And where am I supposed to find them? There's no glass factory around here.
Ever heard about the eggheads in the Swamps? Through their quartermaster — Pakhom, that's his nickname — you can get all kinds of things.
Those Swamps are a long way off…
Prokha, I brought the containers, five of them, just like we agreed. Pour it!
You're quick. The glassware all intact?
Carried them like a maiden, take them.
Yeah, intact. And here's your jar. Carry it carefully too, don't spill it.
I've got a word for you.

Listen, what the hell do you stink of like that? You could at least watch where you step once in a while. Where'd you manage to smear yourself with so much crap? What if the pseudodogs catch the scent? They've got a thing for fleshes, and you reek of them from a mile away. You want something, or just passing through?
Yeah, got myself into it, happens to everyone. When you're running flat out, you don't always notice what kind of crap's under your feet...\nSay, did you buy a shotgun from Baldy?
Hmm, yeah, that did happen. Gave him a "Flash" and a "Meat Chunk" for it. Fair and square. Why the sudden interest? My fragrant friend.
Hey, cool it. Careless words can earn you a solid reply... I've got my own interest in that shotgun.

Don't sulk or you'll burst — or crap your pants again. You've gotta appreciate a joke, otherwise life ain't worth living. As for the shotgun — just between us, it's nothing special, that's why I don't use it. Wasted good artifacts on it, got tempted by the brand name, thought it was from a decent manufacturer. If you really want it, bring back what I lost — and it's yours.
So you specifically need a "Flash" and a "Meat Chunk"?

No, why would I. Any two artifacts of that tier will do. Or one of a higher tier. When you've got them, we'll talk. And you should really clean that crap off your boots — you'll feel calmer yourself, and the air around you will be fresher.
Our deal still on?
Still interested in the shotgun? Brought the artifacts?
Not yet. Haven't made it to my stash.
Brought a couple of second-tier ones.
I've got a really good artifact. I'm handing it over.

Hmm. That'll do. I stashed that shotgun in a hideout. Not far from the tunnel that leads to the Cordon — I was hiding from boars in a bus on the road. Wrapped that little piece of junk in an old backpack and left it there.
I'll try to find it. Hope I won't have to come back — to smash your face in.
Ivan Sergeyevich said you needed help.
Yes, there's one urgent matter. Do you remember our conversation about the biopsy?
You'd better refresh my memory, I've been having some problems with it.

If you're joking, that's good. We were talking about researching mutant tissues. If you've noticed, among specimens of the same species there have started to appear individuals with more pronounced traits — as stalkers put it, seasoned ones. The Zone is changing, and so are the mutants. They adapt quickly, alter their behavior, and become more resistant to external factors. Some even believe they are beginning to show rudimentary intelligence. The Zone works wonders. The evolutionary process that took millions of years on Earth unfolds here in just a matter of years. Studying the genetic code of these creatures and comparing their DNA to earlier samples will provide yet another irrefutable confirmation of the theory of evolution. And it will be of enormous benefit to other fields of science as well. Our colleagues from the capital institute have taken up this problem.
Then let them deal with it. What does it have to do with me?

I promised that, through my own channels, I would get in touch with the Hunters. They'll help with tracking down rare mutants. But to hunt them themselves they... refuse. Some principles of theirs. And you, Marked One, seem to me the most suitable candidate. Legends are already being told about you.
Let's skip that. What exactly do you need from me?
The Hunters reported where they encountered specific mutants. You'll need to bring me parts of their bodies, and I'll handle the processing and preservation of the material myself. Will you help?
And which mutants will I have to hunt?
Bloodsuckers, chimeras, controllers, pseudogiants. They sit at the top of the food chain, and the biotransformation of these organisms proceeds at a much faster pace than in other species.
That's quite a demand! You said it yourself — seasoned ones. So much for all those hunting principles. This isn't chasing dogs and cats through the swamps.
It's clear that killing them isn't easy, but still...
Exactly — not easy. You'll be advancing science here, and I'll be putting my ass on the line. What's the point for me? What exactly do I get out of it?

I'll compensate you for shotgun ammo and medical supplies. Ivan Sergeyevich allocated some funds for these purposes. I can also share information on the sequential modification of the artifact "Pellicle" into more advanced, let's call them that, specimens. Scientists at our institute are working on this problem, even if it's not their main field of activity. I can say they've achieved certain successes, although with the category often referred to as "absolutes" things aren't working out for them yet. Thus, upon completion of the job, you'll receive practically the entire line of transformations, from modificate to hypermodificate.
Not interested. I'll manage without your modifications.
Deal. The main thing is not to regret it later, if I manage in time.
Well then, I'll look for other volunteers.
Believe me, you won't regret it. We can get started right away.
\nA scientist at the Swamp needs to obtain three tentacles from bloodsuckers inhabiting the Dark Valley
Which ones do we start with?
There's a lead on a bloodsucker lair. Will you take it on?
And where should I look for them? I hope not at the edge of the Zone.
I don't have time right now, I'll come by later.
No, it's not far, in the Dark Valley. Hunters reported seeing a pack of those bastards there. Said they were of some special kind, black. Looks like exactly the ones we need.
And what exactly am I supposed to do?
You need to cut three tentacles off them.
I'll try to bring you the tentacles.
Three?! I don't like this idea. Count me out.
I've sent you a marker to their habitat on your PDA. Take these rounds, you'll get more when you return.
That's a shame, then I'll look for someone else.
Man, you really dumped some work on me, barely made it out alive.
So, what about the bloodsuckers?
Just like we agreed, the monsters are dead, I cut three tentacles off them.
What's gonna happen to them, they're chasing dogs around.
These are the right ones? No tricks?
Don't worry, they're the real deal. Take them before they start stinking even more. Nasty creatures, they were.
That's good then... I asked the hunters to pick only seasoned monsters. The DNA we need is found specifically in such specimens.
I've done my part. What about the reward?
Here you go, just like I promised.
Hold on! What about the modificate recipe?
We discussed that right at the very beginning. You'll get the recipes once all the work is done, and you've only completed a quarter of it.
You're a crafty one, covering your bases.
That's true enough, no point hiding it.
\nA scientist at the Swamp needs to obtain three claws from chimeras inhabiting the Gut
What kind of beasts are next on the list?
There's a lead on some seasoned chimeras. Ready to continue the hunt?
And where were they seen?
I don't have time right now, I'll come back later.
You've been to the Gut, right? Hunters reported seeing several specimens we're interested in there.
What's needed this time?
Five claws from those beasts are needed, I think that'll be enough.
What?! Just cutting one takes a ton of running around. You'll burn through a mountain of ammo.
Then... at least three. I'll try to compensate you for ammo and medicine, and I'll chip in for the road.
That changes things, mark where to look for them.
I don't like this idea.
I've sent you the habitat marker on your PDA. And this... for the road.
Suit yourself, I'll look for someone else.
Never again, not after that... Almost got eaten alive.
You're alive though. So what about the chimeras?
Take the claws. Damn, they were some vicious beasts.
What's gonna happen to them, they're frolicking with boars.
I asked the hunters to pick only seasoned monsters. The DNA we need is found precisely in such specimens.
What was it that we agreed on?
Everything's fair and square, just like I promised.
\nA scientist at the Swamp needs to obtain two hands from controllers inhabiting the Swamps
What creatures are next in line?
There's a lead on a couple of controllers.
And where were they seen?
I don't have time right now, I'll come back later.
Hunters reported seeing this spawn right here, in the Swamps.
What's needed this time?
Only two hands are needed. I think that'll be enough.

And how did controllers end up in the Swamps? It was a quiet place... used to be. Dogs barking, boars grunting, tushkanos "murmuring", kitty-cats purring. What's going on... A controller is a dangerous beast, you can't get close to it. You'll need a good rifle, and with optics too.
I won't help you with a rifle. I'll give you ammo and medicine. And I'll try to find something else too. So, what do you say?
Deal, mark where to look for those telepaths.
I don't like this idea.
I've sent you their habitat markers on your PDA.
Suit yourself, I'll look for someone else.
My head is still ringing.
So, what about the controllers?
Take the hands, they're already starting to stink. Damn, they were some vicious creatures.
What's gonna happen to them, just strolling around.
I asked the hunters to pick only seasoned monsters. The DNA we need is found precisely in such specimens.
I've already heard about the seasoned ones. Where's the reward?
The reward awaits its hero.
\nA scientist at the Swamp needs to obtain two paws from pseudogiants inhabiting Agroprom
What other unclean thing is left?
There's a lead on a couple of pseudogiants. So, are you willing to finish our experiment?
And where were they seen?
I don't have time right now, I'll come back later.
At Agroprom, not far from here. They say the place is calm.
Who says so? Maybe I should take you there on a tour, free of charge, interested?
Still joking... Marked One, you and I are practically done already. Just minor details left.
No jokes at all, there are more dogs per square meter there than rats at your base. And you call it minor details. Last time you promised to find something, so where is it? You're cheating.
I remember everything. All that's left is to collect the final specimens... Hunters observed the pseudogiants from a hill, but didn't come close, got scared.
Because they're smart... Alright, mark where to look for them.
I don't like this idea.
I've sent you the marker showing where to head for the giants on your PDA.
Suit yourself, I'll look for someone else.
No way I'm signing up for something like that again.
So, what about the giants?
Take the hands, they're already starting to stink. Damn, they were some vicious creatures.
What's gonna happen to them, they're just stomping around slowly.
I asked the hunters to pick only seasoned monsters. The DNA we need is found precisely in such specimens.
What was it that we agreed on?
Good work! Accept this from all of science and from me personally. If you need anything, I'll always help, within my means.
I'd like to ask about something.
Any problems, or just curious?

That mutant stuff I brought in for biopsy, how did you preserve it, what did you treat it with? Parts of rare mutants are valuable goods, but they spoil fast. Sometimes they just disappear before you can even put them to use. Maybe you can advise what needs to be done to keep them longer. Or preserve them for me, if that's possible.

Preserving mutant parts is a rather troublesome and labor-intensive process. There's also the issue of the preservative. To stabilize the flesh, we use a substance from the "Fruit Punch" anomaly. Here, in the Swamps, this anomaly does not occur. We made an arrangement with a couple of stalkers, and they supply us with the necessary amount of preservative, but the reserves are limited. No one will just hand it over to me for personal needs. Even our quartermaster, Pakhom, has his rats getting their little crumbs strictly by quota.

I'll deal with the preservative, I'll bring as much as needed. Jars are sold by that same Pakhom. You just tell me how many and which parts you're willing to preserve. And how long can they be stored?

They can be stored for quite a long time, provided certain conditions are met. As I understand it, you need to preserve the flesh itself, without any prior processing. That, by the way, will take less time. The preparation process for preservation takes about a day, plus time for the preservative to properly soak into the flesh. So count on this - if you bring it in today, you'll only be able to take it back, should the need arise, in two days, no earlier. The technological process must not be interrupted, otherwise you'll be left with nothing. I warn you right away, in a normal environment, without refrigeration and preservative, tissue spoilage will be the same as before treatment, or even faster.\nIf these terms suit you, then I'll talk to Ivan Sergeich, I think he won't be against it, considering your previous merits. And we ourselves might urgently need something from rare parts. You wouldn't refuse us, would you?
No, of course not. The terms are acceptable. So how many jars should I bring?

One jar is enough to preserve a single part.\nBut in any case, the issue of preservation will have to be handled through our quartermaster. Containers for the preservative, and most importantly the refrigerators, are under his supervision. That's why he's the quartermaster.
I'll come to some kind of agreement with Pakhom.
I wanna talk about a PDA.
What's there to talk about, huh? Or you smack your head again? I already sang it to you — six grand, and the Pee-Dee-A's in your pocket!
I'll take it, I guess. Here's six thousand.
When I've got the cash, I'll take it. Till then — later.
All by the rules. Yours it was — now it's ours. Here's the little thing, take it. Like they say — come on by again. So what, huh? Maybe you'll grab another one?
Yeah, later. Without dough it's rough, I get it myself.
Yeah, I found a way to Pripyat, even went there myself. Rotten place, I'll tell ya. And... well... in that getup of yours you ain't makin' it there — you'll croak on the way in.
You what, sick or somethin'?! My getup ain't good enough for ya? Fancy coat, Stepanych stitched it, top grade.
Maybe top grade, but the situation there's... so-so. The Brain Scorcher's shut down, sure, but it still smacks your brains good, plus radiation, poisoned air. Nah, like that you won't get through.

So that's the layout you're paintin'. Well then, lemme chew on it...\nYeah, got it now... A little shuffle... You bring me a suit, one of them scientific ones, the kind Sakharov's eggheads wear over at Yantar, and I'll give you a tip on a sweet stash. That work for ya? Kinda brotherly, yeah?
Brotherly?! What'd you promise me? I get you a path — you give me a stash tip. How you get there ain't my problem.
Marked One, why you raisin' a wave right off the bat? How was I supposed to know about them hassles. I figured if they killed that brain-crusher, you could slip through easy-like.
You figured. Fraer, that ain't how business works. Either you answer for your talk, or we split and forget this whole thing.

Man, what a stubborn mug, and God just had to stick me with ya. Fine, I'll toss in a dozen more Pee-Dee-As. And if you bring a suit that's mo-de... mu-de... fa-ci-ri-zed... damn, tongue-breaker! Anyway, that green one, seen it maybe? For that you'll get word on another stash too. Honest, tooth I swear. So what, we settled?

Swearin' on his tooth, yeah right. You know how many mugs like you already tossed me their teeth? Plus, I don't see your cut in all this. Why'd you hand me a fat stash, or even two? What's your take? Or is there somethin' else in Pripyat you're ready to strip to your last shirt for?

That ain't for your sick head to worry about. What else is there — that's mine business. Got it? See you got it.\nNow listen up. You gotta sort things out with that noggin of yours, right? Everyone knows you're diggin' dirt on Strelok and his sidekicks. So if we come to terms, I won't point you to just any stash, but for real, to that Fang-toothed guy's hidey-hole... Or whatever they called that handy buddy of Strelok. And I can spill about Strelok's own crib in Pripyat. Back in the day some real serious people were stirrin' deals with him, and I bet they still are, just keepin' it quiet. One of ours, Mishka the Tramp, told me once over a heavy drink. He used to guide them types. That's how they sniffed out Strelok's pad. Tramp poisoned himself on rotgut a few days later and croaked, but the info's solid, not drunk crap. I told no one — not even the boss — just you. Outta respect. So what, we dealin'?

We're dealin'. Even though I'm fed, clothed, and geared just fine, you did hook my interest. Strelok... more and more feels like some kinda myth than a real man. From the stories — he's been everywhere, left his stink everywhere, but nobody really knows squat about him.

What'd you expect, he's a big-shot, not some riffraff, a seasoned stalker through and through. Truth be told, the whole Strelok thing's fishy. Not many dealt with him and his crew straight up. Those who did are damn hard to find, or keep their mouths shut. And some the Zone swallowed whole. But that he was here and stirred up hell — that's a sure thing. Even now some folks got tails hangin' on 'em, walkin' around, lookin' over their shoulders.
Alright, I'll try to get you a good suit. I'll send the route anyway. With a life like this, maybe we won't see each other again.
I brought you the scientific suit, hope the size works.
Now that's respect, brother, real respect! Always knew I could count on you. Been feelin' it — you're a straight guy, not some flashy bullshitter like most stalkers.
Listen, I'm beat. Let's cut the fenya and get to business. Take the suit. Where's my cut?

What kinda difa... ram-bos? Ah, forget it. Listen close.\nIn Pripyat, on the central square, right across from the monument to "our bright future", there's a cross — can't miss it. Who they buried there, I ain't in the know, but that don't matter. That grave's where Fix stashed his junk. What's in there... even a naked hedgehog knows the loot's gotta be solid, you don't haul booze and grub all the way to Pripyat.

What kinda difa... ram-bos? Ah, forget it. Listen close.\nIn Pripyat, on the central square, right across from the monument to "our bright future", there's a cross — can't miss it. Who they buried there, I ain't in the know, but that don't matter. That grave's where Fix stashed his junk. What's in there... even a naked hedgehog knows the loot's gotta be solid, you don't haul booze and grub all the way to Pripyat. That's one.\nNow number two. In the center of Pripyat there's a hotel, used to be a fancy bughouse, they say. Somewhere round the second floor Strelok set up his crib. Rummage there proper, you're bound to dig up somethin'. I got a feelin' there's a fat score waitin'.

Alright, I'll check it out. Don't forget to toss in the Pee-Dee-As — you promised.\nStill, I'm curious: if you knew about this stash way back, why spill it to me now? Coulda grabbed the junk yourself when you had the chance. If it's really there, that is...

Marked One, you smack your head again or just playin' dumb? I told you — "serious people" stand behind all this. I don't need extra headaches later. I come in quiet, do my thing, and leave quiet. That's it, I ain't comin' back here. Enough, Fraer's done runnin'. Bottom line — stop grillin' me.\nHere, take your Pee-Dee-As. Happy now?
Look at him, playin' James Bond over here... Later, conspirator.
Greetings, Comrade Warrant Officer!
First — Senior Warrant Officer, and second — what do you want?
Down to business then... Need to swipe one little paper from your "HQ". You drink tea with the commander in the evenings, right? Maybe you could, uh... arrange somethin'?
Finish your thought. Who I drink tea with and when ain't your concern. What exactly do you need?
I need an order "No... dated...".
Why you need it? Ah, whatever. For a crate of the good stuff I'll get it. Come back in an hour.
Got it. I'll try to scrape together twenty bottles.
\nSenior Warrant Officer Sherstyuk is willing to bring an order for the Deserter in exchange for twenty bottles of vodka
About that paper with the order... Vodka's here!
Ah, good lad! Solid work, Rus... Come on, don't stall.
